content: Each year, Congress funds the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) to renew over 2.1 million Section 8 vouchers, which are rental subsidies for low-income families in the private market. These vouchers help cover the difference between rent and the tenant's contribution (30% of adjusted income). The Section 8 voucher program provides rental subsidies for low-income families in the private market. The cost of a voucher to a Public Housing Agency (PHA) is the difference between the tenant's actual rent or the maximum subsidy level set by the PHA and 30% of the tenant's income. Cost fluctuates with changes in tenant incomes, rents, and payment standards. Congress and HUD have made changes to the program in recent years. In recent years, Congress has made changes to the Section 8 voucher program, leading to funding uncertainty for many Public Housing Agencies (PHAs). This has put pressure on Congress to adopt a permanent funding formula, possibly through Section 8 voucher reform legislation.
